titlestmt.title: There is No Natural Religion copy A : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 90KB; 22 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 70KB to 520KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesAugust 2015
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of There is No Natural Religion, copies A, D, and M, from the British Museum, Houghton Library, and Victoria and Albert Museum respectively. They join copy B, from Yale Center for British Art, copy C, from the Library of Congress, and copies G1-2 and L, from the Morgan Library and Museum. The Archive now has all seven extant copies of this illuminated book, making There is No Natural Religion the sixth illuminated book with its entire publishing history reproduced in the Archive, joining The Song of Los, Milton a Poem, All Religions are One, The Book of Ahania, and The Book of Los. The Archive will add The Marriage of Heaven and Hell to the list later this year. There is No Natural Religion was composed and executed in 1788, shortly after All Religions are One. These were Blake's first works in illuminated printing, though no copy of either work survives from this date. Blake composed twenty plates for There is No Natural Religion plates in two antithetical sets (a and b series). Only copy L consists exclusively of the ten b series of plates. The other twelve recorded copies of this book share impressions of the same group of either eight or twelve plates, which appeared to be merely incomplete sets of impressions until it was discovered that six of these copies were 19th-century reproductions. Once the inauthentic impressions were weeded out, it became apparent that what remained was Blake's selection of a and b plates for an abridged version of the work printed around 1794.
With the publication of There is No Natural Religion copies A, D, and M, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 95 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all copies of There is No Natural Religion in the Archive. With the Archive's Compare feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across all or selected copies of this or any of the other illuminated books and, with the Virtual Lightbox, users can examine any images in the Archive, as well as crop, zoom, and juxtapose them for close study.
In addition to illuminated books, the Archive contains many important manuscripts and series of engravings, sketches, and water color drawings, including Blake's illustrations to Thomas Gray's Poems, water color and engraved illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy, the large color printed drawings of 1795 and c. 1805, the Linnell and Butts sets of the Book of Job water colors and the sketchbook containing drawings for the engraved illustrations to the Book of Job, the water color illustrations to Robert Blair's The Grave, and all nine of Blake's water color series illustrating the poetry of John Milton.
In December 2014, the Archive launched a new wing, which contains searchable HTML and PDF editions of thirty-nine past issues of Blake/An Illustrated Quarterly published from 2000 through 2009. PDF versions present the journal as originally published, but the HTML versions are re-implemented with many full-color images from the Blake Archive, making it possible for users to link directly to those works that have been published in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: Michael Fox Project Manager: Joseph Fletcher Project Coordinator, University of Rochester: Laura Bell Consultants on Special Projects: Rachel Lee, Ashley Reed Bibliographer: Mark Crosby Project Assistants: Katherine Calvin, Adam Engel, Andrea Everett, Jarrod Ingles, Rachael Isom, Shannon Jaime, Gabrielle Kiriloff, Mary Learner, Eric Loy, Adam McCune, Scott Robinson, Hardeep Sidhu, Margaret Speer, Lisa Vandenbossche, Nikolaus Wasmoen, Alia Wegner, Megan Wilson

changestmt.change: BAD created, transcription established, and illustration description created
changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: William Shaw Project Manager: Ashley Reed Bibliographer: Mark Crosby Project Assistants: Esther Arnold, Kate Attkisson, Laura Bell, Lauren Cameron, Katherine Carlson, Robin Curry, Cassandra Etter-Wenzel, Andrea Everett, Joseph Fletcher, Elizabeth Goodfellow, Rachel Lee, Ali McGhee, Jennifer Park, Adair Rispoli, Sarah Shaw, Sarah Tolf, Joseph Vogel, Nikolaus Wasmoen, Bihan Zhang

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist "The Author & Printer W Blake" is etched in reverse at the bottom of object 1. In this copy, the lettering is partly obscured by hand coloring.

imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not given in the work, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition and etching.

objinfo.objorder: Bentley plates a1, a3-a9, b3, b4, b12 The plates were apparently loose in 1862 (see the note on provenance), but have been bound at least twice. The present binding order (Bentley plates a3, b3, a5-a9, b4, b12, a1) makes no sense and could not possibly represent Blake's ordering. Consequently, the objects have been arranged here according to a normal sequence, with the frontispiece first, then the "Argument" plate, then the "a" plates in sequence (as established by their heading numbers) followed by the "b" plates with the plate headed "Therefore" last.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 4.7 x 3.7 cm. and 6.1 x 4.6 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with touches of white-line etching on some objects
objinfo.printingstyle: relief, probably with rudimentary color printing on objects 1-5, 8-11 and hand tinting with water colors on all objectsThe hand tinting on objects 3-11 is in black wash only.
objinfo.etchednumbers: noneThe etched numbers (I-VI, I-II) are headings, not plate numbers.
objinfo.binding: The plates are mounted in paper windows bound in red morocco in 1969.The plates were probably loose in 1862, but at a later date (and until 1969) mounted on stubs and bound in green morocco. See the note on Object Order.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably passed by inheritance from Blake to his wife Catherine in 1827; probably by inheritance to Frederick Tatham in 1831; probably among the fifty plates "from a very small work," including "some duplicates," sold anonymously (probably from Tatham's collection) at Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 197 (16s. to Richard Monckton Milnes, later Lord Houghton); Francis Turner Palgrave; given to the British Museum by Palgrave in Jan. 1878.

desc.objtitle:
There is No Natural Religion,
object 1 (Bentley a1, Erdman a1, Keynes a2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two youthful males, both nude and with curly hair, stand on the right. The youth farthest to the right appears to have his left arm raised and may have his left hand resting on the tree trunk near the right margin. The youth farthest to the left holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints as only a barely-visible line. On the left is a seated couple; both the old man, with a long beard, and the woman wear gowns. The man appears to be seated on a fluted pillar. The woman may be wearing drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Another tree stands along the left margin; its branches and leaves form a canopy over the seated figures. Mountains dominate the distant landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands on the right. He appears to have his left arm raised, perhaps with his left hand resting on the tree trunk near the right margin. His right arm is at his side. His body suggests a contrapposto posture. He looks down and to the left.

A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands to the left of another such figure. He holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints only as a barely-visible line (drawn clearly in pen and ink in copies D, G, M). Both arms are at his side. His face is partly turned to the right; he may be looking at his companion.

An old, bearded man with long hair sits on a fluted pillar. He wears a long gown and looks to the right. His right arm is slightly bent and may rest on the pillar that he is seated on; his left arm appears to rest on his knee.
A woman sits behind and to the right of the old bearded man. She wears a gown and has drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Her left arm rests at her side. Her face is partly turned to the right.
A tree stands on the right. Its branches and perhaps some leaves spread out near the top of the plate.
A tree stands on the left. Its branches and leaves form a canopy at the top of the plate.
The old, bearded man on the left sits on what appears to be a fluted pillar.
The landscape background is dominated by two ranges of hills or mountains, perhaps marked by indeterminate vegetation.

lg.l: The Author & Printer W BlakeIn reverse lettering, partly obscured by hand coloring.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 2 (Bentley a3, Erdman a3, Keynes a3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The center of the design is dominated by a seated figure, probably female, wearing a long gown. Her legs are crossed and she holds a book or tablet on her right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. On the right is a much smaller standing figure, probably a young girl. She is gowned and may be holding a book or piece of paper from which she reads. On the left is a figure—perhaps a young boy—lying on the ground but with his torso propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing in a book. There are two trees near the right margin and another, with a vine around its trunk near the left margin. The design would seem to relate to the theme of "Education" (E2) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A seated figure, probably female, holds a book or tablet on her prominent right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. Her legs are crossed and her upper body is slightly twisted to the right.
A gowned figure, perhaps a young girl, stands right of the larger, seated figure. She looks down and to the left and perhaps reads in a book or a piece of paper she holds in her hands.

A figure, perhaps a young boy, lies on the ground left of the larger seated figure. His torso is propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing (with his right hand) in a book.
Two trees, with indications of branches and leaves, grow near the right margin.
A tree, or at least the trunk of a tree, grows near the left margin. A vine spirals around this tree. There are indications of leaves growing from the tree or vine.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several representational images hover around or on the letters of the heading ("The Argument"). These are, from left to right, a figure hovering above the space between the two words; a figure standing but leaning against the left diagonal of the "A"; a figure right of the right diagonal of the "A," probably reaching up and to the right toward a bird hovering above the "u" and "m." It is unclear whether we are viewing the figures on the "A" from the front or the back. The first and last letters of the heading terminate in vine-like decorations. Other vines, one with a single loop, extend between the heading and the first line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure hovers between the two words of the heading. He or she may be looking down toward the figure just below and to the right.
A figure stands but leans against the left diagonal of the "A." It is unclear whether we are seeing the figure from the front or the back.

A figure stands just right of the second diagonal of the "A" in "Argument." It is unclear whether we are seeing the figure from the front or the back. The figure's arm on the left may be raised horizontally to hold onto the letter.

A bird with extended wings flies above the "u" and "m" of "Argument." The direction of its flight is unclear, but the long extensions both right and left suggest a long neck (hence, a swan, crane, or stork?) and a long tail.
The ends of the "T" on the far left terminate in vine-like decorations.
The ends of the "t" terminate in vine-like decorations.
Vines, one with a single loop, extend between the heading and the first line of text.

lg.l: Man has no notion of moral
Naturally he is only a natu-

desc.objtitle:
,
object 3 (Bentley a4, Erdman a4, Keynes a4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a large staff or walking stick and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. He may be bald, but perhaps with a forelock. The background landscape includes a small hill and a clump of trees on the left. A tree grows near the right margin in the foreground. One branch forms a canopy over the old man; another branch climbs along the right margin. A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and the branch near the upper right margin. This vine continues horizontally along the top of the plate. There there may be two birds, or bird-like sprigs of vegetation, just left and right of the heading number ("I").

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a staff or walking stick. He faces left and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. He may be bald, but perhaps with a forelock. His left arm is bent at the elbow, the forearm extended upward along the staff.
A dog lies on the ground, front legs spread apart. He faces right and looks up to the old man on the right.
Forms just left and right of the heading number ("I") might be flying birds rather than part of the vegetation.
A tree grows near the right margin. One of its branches, perhaps bearing leaves, arches above the old man and dog. Another branch curves upward along the right margin.
A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and its branch near the right margin. The vine continues horizontally along the top margin of the plate, where it may bear a few leaves.
A clump of trees fills the landscape background on the left.
A low hill fills the landscape to the right and left of the old man. Given the distance and perspective, this hill rises between his knees and hips.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 4 (Bentley a5, Erdman a5, Keynes a5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around with waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured). The child, also kneeling and facing right, is probably male; there are no clear indications of clothing. He extends his arms horizontally toward a small bird near the right margin. These motifs may relate to the theme of "desires" (E2) first raised textually on plate a8. The background, right of the woman and above the child, is filled with a clump of trees. A large, leafless tree grows up the left margin and spreads a branch between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured).

A young child, probably male and with no clear indications of clothing, kneels on the ground and faces to the right. His hair may be curly. While being held by a woman on the left, the child reaches, arms extended horizontally, toward a small bird near the right margin.
A bird flies to the right, away from the grasp of a child.
The landscape background is filled with leafy trees.
A leafless tree grows up the left margin. One of its branches extends between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 5 (Bentley a6, Erdman a6, Keynes a6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He may be wearing a gown, as indicated by folds over his left hip. He is facing to the left and reaching with both arms in the same direction. His legs are extended horizontally to the left. A winged and nude putto, visible from the waist up, appears behind the seated man's legs. This second figure looks to the right and reaches toward, and perhaps touches, the seated man's right shoulder with his left hand. The putto's right arm is raised, with one finger of his right hand pointing heavenward. This gesture, and simply the winged child himself, may indicate the spiritual perceptions not available to the "3 senses" (E2). A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals. There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left.

component.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He may be wearing a gown, as indicated by folds over his left hip. He is facing to the left, with legs extended in the same direction, and reaching with both arms to the left.

A winged putto, seen from the waist up, appears behind the legs of the seated man. The putto's left arm is extended horizontally; his left hand reaches toward, and may touch, the right shoulder of the seated man. The putto's right arm is raised and a finger on his right hand points heavenward. There are no clear indications of clothing, though his hair appears to be short.
A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals.
A vine is intertwined around the tree or vine growing up the right margin. This second vine seems to end in the top right corner; the larger tree or vine extends horizontally to the left margin.
There may be some plants left of the putto, lower left.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 6 (Bentley a7, Erdman a7, Keynes a7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be feathers. The landscape on the right is composed of a low hill and a grove of trees. A single tree extends up the left margin, although in this copy it can barely be seen left of the text. Three birds fly in the sky above the text and on each side of the heading number ("IV").

component.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be two or three feathers. He may also wear a hoop earring in his right ear.
The landscape above the seated figure includes a low hill and a grove of trees (covered, in this copy, with a gray wash, almost completely obscuring these motifs).
A tree grows up the left margin, although in this copy it can barely be seen left of the text. One short branch arches to the right near the top of the plate.
Three birds fly above the text, one left of the heading number ("IV") and two right of the number.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 7 (Bentley a8, Erdman a8, Keynes a8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy with curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan floating on a small body of water (perhaps a river or lake). The boy's gestures suggest the theme of "Mans desires" (E2) in the text. A tree, with an intertwined vine, grows up the left margin. One of the tree's branches, perhaps bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate. A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy with short, curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan on the left.
A duck or swan floats on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river. The bird faces to the right.
A tree grows up the left margin of the plate. One of its branches, bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate.
A vine is entwined around the lower half of the tree near the left margin.
The bird lower left appears to be floating on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river.
A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 8 (Bentley a9, Erdman a9, Keynes a9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand. The long, spiky leaves of two plants, or exceptionally long grasses, arch over his head from both the right and left sides of the plate. A tree grows up the right margin; its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top of the plate. A vine is entwined around the tree's trunk. One tendril of the vine terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand.
The long leaves of two plants, or very long grasses, arch over the figure.
A tree grows up the right margin. Its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top margin of the plate.
A vine is intertwined around the tree near the right margin of the plate. One of the vine's tendrils terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 9 (Bentley b3, Erdman b3, Keynes b3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned man, with curly hair and a long beard, lies on the ground. He props up his upper body on his elbows and apparently reads, or writes with his left hand, in a book on the ground before him. On the left is a clump of vegetation or perhaps the stump of a tree.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned man, with curly hair and a long beard, lies on the ground. He props up his upper body on his elbows and apparently reads, or writes with his left hand, in a book on the ground before him.
There is a clump of vegetation, or perhaps the stump of a tree, in the lower left corner of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 10 (Bentley b4, Erdman b4, Keynes b4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly on his back. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. His head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone. He may be sleeping or dead. Above and to the right of his head is a small figure hovering in the air and facing to the left. Its legs are spread apart and at least one arm is extended horizontally to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly supine. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead.
A very small figure hovers above the supine figure's head. It faces left, legs spread apart and with at least one arm raised horizontally and extended to the left.
The supine figure's head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II"). Right of the number is a vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II").
A vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries fills the space right of the heading number ("II").

desc.objtitle:
,
object 11 (Bentley b12, Erdman b12, Keynes b12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, or—if he is of great size—on hills. His legs appear to be crossed at the knees. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (E3) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, or—if he is of great size—on hills. His legs appear to be crossed at the knees. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (E3) in the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vines decorate the spaces on all sides of the first line of text ("Therefore"). A single vine appears above the first four letters. Left of the word is a vine with three branches. A vine with a single loop and perhaps some leaves grows at the end of the word. Two vines lie beneath the word; the one on the right has a single loop and terminates in three leaves or small flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine descends into the margin left of the word "Therefore." Another vine appears above the first four letters of "Therefore."
A vine with a single loop and perhaps long, slender leaves at its termination appears in the margin right of "Therefore."
A vine, perhaps with a few small leaves, appears under the first four letters of "Therefore."
A vine with a single loop appears beneath and to the right of the last four letters of "Therefore." It terminates in three leaves or small flowers.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").

component.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.
